graphics

numpytools.py

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 """
00002 Unified interface to Numeric, numarray, and numpy
00003 =================================================
00004 
00005 This module imports Numeric, numarray, or numpy, plus some other
00006 useful functions for numerical computing. Numeric, numarray, and numpy
00007 can be viewed as three different implementations of Numerical Python
00008 functionality.  The present module enables writing scripts that are
00009 independent of the particular choice of Numeric, numarray, or
00010 numpy. That is, the idea is that any of these modules can be replaced
00011 by one of the alternatives, and the script should still work. This
00012 requires the script to only use the set of instructions that are
00013 common to Numeric, numarray, and numpy.
00014 
00015 One reason for wanting the flexibility is that the different
00016 implementations may exhibit different computational efficiency in
00017 different applications. It also makes it trivial to adopt new versions
00018 of Numerical Python in old scripts.
00019 
00020 
00021 Basic Usage
00022 -----------
00023 
00024 To achieve a script that makes transparent use of Numeric, numarray, and
00025 numpy, one needs to do one of the following imports::
00026 
00027   from graphics.numpytools import *
00028   # or
00029   import graphics.numpytools as N
00030 
00031 Then one should never explicitly import Numeric, numarray, or numpy,
00032 and explicitly use functions in these modules as this may cause
00033 different array types to be mixed in the same application. Only call
00034 the functions that were imported by the star or prefix functions by
00035 the N symbol.
00036 
00037 
00038 What Gets Imported?
00039 -------------------
00040 
00041 All symbols from either Numeric, numarray, or numpy are imported
00042 into the global namespace of this numpytools module::
00043 
00044   from Numeric import *
00045   #or
00046   from numarray import *
00047   #or
00048   from numpy import *
00049 
00050 Also the RandomArray, LinearAlgebra, MLab, and FFT modules are imported.
00051 One problem with switching between Numeric, numarray, and numpy is that
00052 the mentioned modules have different names in the three packages. For
00053 example::
00054 
00055   Numeric has LinearAlgebra
00056   numarray has numarray.linear_algebra.LinearAlgebra2
00057   numpy has numpy.linalg
00058 
00059 By default, we use the old well-established names introduced by Numeric
00060 and import the linear algebra modules of numarray and numpy under the
00061 classic name LinearAlgebra. Similarly, the other modules are also
00062 imported under the Numeric names: RandomArray, RNG, MLab, and FFT.
00063 RNG is not supported by numarray, while with numpy RNG becomes identical
00064 to RandomArray.
00065 
00066 Note that the MA module is not imported since it redefines
00067 the repr function (array([1,2]) becomes [1,2] as for a list) if
00068 the Numeric is used. The user must always explicitly import this package
00069 if Numeric is used as basic array module.
00070 
00071 Note that the numpytools module also makes some extensions of Numerical
00072 Python available, see the section "Functionality of this module that
00073 extends Numerical Python" (below).
00074 
00075 
00076 What to use: Numeric, numarray, or numpy?
00077 -----------------------------------------
00078 
00079 The present module defines a global variable basic_NumPy holding
00080 either "Numeric", "numarray", or "numpy", depending on which module
00081 that was actually imported.
00082 
00083 To determine whether Numeric, numarray, or numpy is to be imported,
00084 the following procedure is applied:
00085 
00086   1. The command line arguments are checked for a --numarray,
00087      --Numeric, or --numpy option.
00088    
00089   2. If the user has already imported Numeric or numarray by an::
00090 
00091      import Numeric
00092      #or
00093      import numarray
00094      #or
00095      import numpy
00096 
00097      statement, the present module continues to import from the same
00098      module (module in sys.modules is used to check whether it should
00099      be Numeric, numarray, or numpy). If the user has imported more than
00100      one of the three module alternatives, numpy is used.
00101    
00102   3. The environment variable NUMPYARRAY is checked.
00103      If this variable contains "numarray", "Numeric", or "numpy" the
00104      corresponding module is imported.
00105 
00106 If neither 1., 2., nor 3. determines the import, i.e., the user has not
00107 explicitly indicated what to use, old and safe Numeric is the default
00108 choice.
00109 
00110 
00111 Functionality of this module that extends Numerical Python:
00112 -----------------------------------------------------------
00113 
00114 Some frequently standard modules like sys, os, and operator are
00115 imported into the namespace of the present module.
00116 
00117 The following extensions to Numerical Python are also defined:
00118 
00119  - sequence:
00120            sequence(a,b,s, [type]) computes numbers from a up to and
00121            including b in steps of s and (default) type float
00122  - seq:
00123            same as sequence (short form)
00124 
00125  - isequence:
00126            as sequence, but integer counters are computed
00127            (isequence is an alternative to range where the
00128            upper limit is included in the sequence)
00129  - iseq:
00130            same as isequence (short form)
00131 
00132  - arr:
00133            simplified interface to creating NumPy arrays (see its doc string)
00134 
00135  - NumPyArray:
00136            the type used in isinstance(a,NumPyArray) for
00137            checking if a is a NumPy array
00138 
00139  - arrmin, arrmax:
00140            compute maximum and minimum of all array entries
00141            (same as amin(a,None) and amax(a,None) in scipy)
00142 
00143  - array_output_precision(n):
00144            print arrays with n decimals
00145 
00146  - solve_tridiag_linear_system:
00147            returns the solution of a tridiagonal linear system
00148 
00149  - wrap2callable:
00150            tool for turning constants, discrete data, string
00151            formulas, function objects, or plain functions
00152            into an object that behaves as a function
00153 
00154  - NumPy_array_iterator:
00155            allows iterating over all array elements using
00156            a single, standard for loop (for value, index in iterator)
00157              
00158  - basic_NumPy:
00159            string containing "Numeric", "numarray", or "numpy",
00160            depending on which of the modules that was imported
00161 
00162  - float_eq:
00163            operator == for float operands with tolerance,
00164            float_eq(a,b,tol) means abs(a-b) < tol
00165            works for both scalar and array arguments
00166 
00167  - norm_L2, norm_l2, norm_L1, norm_l1, norm_inf: 
00168            norms for multi-dimensional arrays viewed as vectors
00169 
00170  - NumPy_version:
00171            holds the version of Numeric, numarray, or numpy
00172 
00173  - NumPy_type:
00174            returns the type of an array, i.e., "Numeric", "numarray",
00175            or "numpy"
00176            
00177  - fortran_storage:
00178            transparent transform of an array to column major (Fortran) storage
00179            that preserves the nature (Numeric, numarray, numpy) of the array
00180 """
00181            
00182 import os, sys, operator, math
00183 
00184 # first task: determine whether to use Numeric or numarray
00185 
00186 basic_NumPy = None  # will later hold 'Numeric' or 'numarray'
00187 
00188 # check the command line (this code is similar to matplotlib.numerix):
00189 if basic_NumPy is None:
00190     if hasattr(sys, 'argv'):  # Apache mod_python has no argv
00191         for _a in sys.argv:
00192             if _a in ["--Numeric", "--numeric", "--NUMERIC"]:
00193                 basic_NumPy = 'Numeric'
00194                 break
00195             if _a in ["--Numarray", "--numarray", "--NUMARRAY"]:
00196                 basic_NumPy = 'numarray'
00197                 break
00198             if _a in ["--NumPy", "--numpy", "--NUMPY"]:
00199                 basic_NumPy = 'numpy'
00200                 break
00201         del _a  # don't pollute the global namespace
00202 
00203 # check if the user has already done an import Numeric, import numarray,
00204 # or import numpy; use the module that was imported
00205 #if basic_NumPy is None:
00206 #    if 'numpy' in sys.modules:
00207 #        basic_NumPy = 'numpy'
00208 #    elif 'numarray' in sys.modules:
00209 #        basic_NumPy = 'numarray'
00210 #    elif 'Numeric' in sys.modules:
00211 #        basic_NumPy = 'Numeric'
00212 
00213 # check the environment variable NUMPYARRAY:
00214 if basic_NumPy is None:
00215     if os.environ.has_key('NUMPYARRAY'):
00216         if   os.environ['NUMPYARRAY'] == 'numpy':
00217             basic_NumPy = 'numpy'
00218         elif os.environ['NUMPYARRAY'] == 'numarray':
00219             basic_NumPy = 'numarray'
00220         elif os.environ['NUMPYARRAY'] == 'Numeric':
00221             basic_NumPy = 'Numeric'
00222 
00223 # final default choice:
00224 if basic_NumPy is None:
00225     basic_NumPy = 'numpy'#'Numeric'
00226 
00227 #print 'from', basic_NumPy, 'import *'
00228 
00229 # table of equivalent names of Numerical Python modules:
00230 # (used to import modules under Numeric, numarray, or numpy name)
00231 _NumPy_modules = (
00232     ('Numeric', 'numarray', 'numpy'),
00233     # umath and Precision are included as part of Numeric, numarray, numpy
00234     ('LinearAlgebra', 'numarray.linear_algebra.LinearAlgebra2',
00235      'numpy.linalg'),
00236     ('RandomArray', 'numarray.random_array.RandomArray2', 'numpy.random'),
00237     ('RNG', '', 'numpy.random'),
00238     ('FFT', 'numarray.fft', 'numpy.fft'),
00239     #('MLab', 'numarray.linear_algebra.mlab', 'numpy.lib.mlab'),
00240     ('MA', 'numarray.ma.MA', 'numpy.core.ma'),
00241     )
00242      
00243 
00244 if basic_NumPy == 'numpy':
00245     try:
00246         for Numeric_name, dummy1, numpy_name in _NumPy_modules[1:]:
00247             if numpy_name == 'RNG':
00248                 import numpy.random
00249                 RNG = numpy.random
00250             elif numpy_name != '':
00251                 exec 'import %s as %s' % (numpy_name, Numeric_name)
00252 
00253         from numpy import *
00254         from numpy import newaxis as NewAxis
00255         from numpy import float as Float
00256 
00257     except ImportError, e:
00258         raise ImportError, '%s\nnumpy import failed!\n'\
00259         'see doc of %s module for how to choose Numeric instead' % \
00260         (e, __name__)

00262     def array_output_precision(no_of_decimals):
00263         """Set no of decimals in printout of arrays."""
00264         arrayprint.set_precision(no_of_decimals)
00265 
00266     def arrmax(a):
00267         """Compute the maximum of all the entries in a."""
00268         try:
00269             return a.max()
00270         except AttributeError:
00271             # not a NumPy array
00272             if operator.isSequenceType(a):
00273                 return max(a)  # does not work for nested sequences
00274             elif operator.isNumberType(a):
00275                 return a
00276             else:
00277                 raise TypeError, 'arrmax of %s not supported' % type(a)        
00278 
00279     def arrmin(a):
00280         """Compute the minimum of all the entries in a."""
00281         try:
00282             return a.min()
00283         except AttributeError:
00284             # not a NumPy array
00285             if operator.isSequenceType(a):
00286                 return min(a)  # does not work for nested sequences
00287             elif operator.isNumberType(a):
00288                 return a
00289             else:
00290                 raise TypeError, 'arrmin of %s not supported' % type(a)
00291 
00292     NumPyArray = ndarray
00293 
00294 if basic_NumPy == 'numarray':
00295     try:
00296         for Numeric_name, numarray_name, dummy1 in _NumPy_modules[1:]:
00297             if numarray_name:
00298                 exec 'import %s as %s' % (numarray_name, Numeric_name)
00299 
00300         # RNG is not supported, make an object that gives an error message:
00301         class __Dummy:
00302             def __getattr__(self, name):
00303                 raise ImportError, 'You have chosen the numarray package, '\
00304                 'but it does not have the functionality of the RNG module'
00305         RNG = __Dummy()
00306         
00307         from numarray import *

00310         raise ImportError, '%s\nnumarray import failed!\n'\

00344     NumPyArray = NumArray
00345 
00346 if basic_NumPy == 'Numeric':
00347     try:
00348         for Numeric_name, dummy1, dummy2 in _NumPy_modules[1:]:
00349             if Numeric_name != 'MA':  # exclude MA, see comment above
00350                 exec 'import %s' % Numeric_name
00351 
00352         from Numeric import *
00353 
00354         # the following is perhaps not a good idea;
00355         # Numeric.UserArray and numarray.NumArray have different
00356         # data attributes!
00357         from UserArray import UserArray as NumArray
00358 
00359         # hack - as long as LinearAlgebra.eigenvalues hang, try to
00360         # get functions from numarray or numpy:
00361         try:
00362             import numpy.linalg as _N
00363         except:
00364             try:
00365                 import numarray.linear_algebra.LinearAlgebra2 as _N
00366             except:
00367                 pass  # nothing to do :-(
00368         try:
00369             LinearAlgebra.eigenvalues = _N.eigenvalues
00370             LinearAlgebra.eigenvectors = _N.eigenvectors
00371             del _N
00372         except NameError:
00373             # no numarray or numpy:
00374             print 'WARNING: LinearAlgebra.eigenvalues hangs!'
00375 
00376         
00377     except ImportError, e:
00378         raise ImportError, '%s\nNumeric import failed!\n'\
00379         'see doc of %s module for how to choose numarray instead' % \
00380         (e, __name__)
00381 
00382     # fix of matrixmultiply bug in Numeric (according to Fernando Perez,
00383     # SciPy-dev mailing list, Sep 28, 2004:
00384     # http://www.scipy.net/pipermail/scipy-dev/2004-September/002267.html,
00385     # matrixmultiply is dot if not dotblas is used, otherwise dot is
00386     # imported from dotblas, and matrixmultiply becomes the unoptimized
00387     # version (Perez timed the difference to be 0.55 vs 122.6 on his
00388     # computer)):
00389     matrixmultiply = dot

00395     def arrmax(a):
00396         """Compute the maximum of all the entries in a."""
00397         # could set arrmax = amax in scipy if scipy is installed
00398         try:
00399             return max(a.flat)  # use Python's list min
00400         except AttributeError:
00401             # not a NumPy array
00402             if operator.isSequenceType(a):
00403                 return max(a)
00404             elif operator.isNumberType(a):
00405                 return a
00406             else:
00407                 raise TypeError, 'arrmax of %s not supported' % type(a)
00408

00413             return min(a.flat)
00414         except AttributeError:
00415             # not a NumPy array
00416             if operator.isSequenceType(a):
00417                 return min(a)
00418             elif operator.isNumberType(a):
00419                 return a
00420             else:
00421                 raise TypeError, 'arrmin of %s not supported' % type(a)

00435 def sequence(min=0.0, max=None, inc=1.0, type=float,
00436              return_type='NumPyArray'):
00437     """
00438     Generate numbers from min to (and including!) max,
00439     with increment of inc. Safe alternative to arange/arrayrange.
00440     The return_type string governs the type of the returned
00441     sequence of numbers ('NumPyArray', 'list', or 'tuple').
00442     """
00443     if max is None: # allow sequence(3) to be 0., 1., 2., 3.
00444         # take 1st arg as max, min as 0, and inc=1
00445         max = min; min = 0.0; inc = 1.0
00446     r = arange(min, max + inc/2.0, inc, type)
00447     if return_type == 'NumPyArray':
00448         return r
00449     elif return_type == 'list':
00450         return r.tolist()
00451     elif return_type == 'tuple':
00452         return tuple(r.tolist())
00453 
00454 seq = sequence # short form
00455 
00456 def isequence(start=0, stop=None, inc=1):
00457     """
00458     Generate integers from start to (and including) stop,
00459     with increment of inc. Alternative to range/xrange.
00460     """
00461     if stop is None: # allow isequence(3) to be 0, 1, 2, 3
00462         # take 1st arg as stop, start as 0, and inc=1
00463         stop = start; start = 0; inc = 1
00464     return xrange(start, stop+inc, inc)
00465 
00466 iseq = isequence
00467 
00468 
00469 def arr(shape=None, element_type=float, data=None, copy=True, file_=None):
00470     """
00471     Compact and flexible interface for creating NumPy arrays.
00472 
00473     @param shape:        length of each dimension
00474     @type  shape:        tuple or int
00475     @param data:         list, tuple, or NumPy array with data elements
00476     @param copy:         copy data if true, share data if false
00477     @type  copy:         boolean
00478     @param element_type: float, Int, Complex, float32, etc.
00479     @param file_:        filename or file object containing array data
00480     @type  file_:        string
00481     @return:             created Numerical Python array
00482 
00483     The array can be created in three ways:
00484     
00485       1. as zeros (just shape specified),
00486 
00487       2. as a copy of or reference to (depending on copy=True,False resp.)
00488          a list, tuple, or NumPy array (provided as the data argument),
00489 
00490       3. from data in a file (for one- or two-dimensional real-valued arrays).
00491 
00492     The function calls the underlying NumPy functions zeros and array
00493     (see the NumPy manual for the functionality of these functions).
00494     In case of data in a file, the first line determines the number of
00495     columns in the array. The file format is just rows and columns
00496     with numbers, no decorations (square brackets, commas, etc.) are
00497     allowed.
00498 
00499     >>> arr((3,4))
00500     array([[ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.],
00501            [ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.],
00502            [ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.]])
00503     >>> somelist=[[0,1],[5,5]]
00504     >>> a = arr(data=somelist)
00505     >>> b = a + 1
00506     >>> c = arr(data=b, copy=False)  # let c share data with b
00507     >>> b is c
00508     True
00509     >>> id(b) == id(c)
00510     True
00511     >>> arr(4, element_type=Int) + 4  # integer array
00512     array([4, 4, 4, 4])
00513 
00514     >>> # make a file with array data:
00515     >>> f = open('tmp.dat', 'w')
00516     >>> f.write('''\
00517     ... 1 3
00518     ... 2 6
00519     ... 3 12
00520     ... 3.5 20
00521     ... ''')
00522     >>> f.close()
00523     >>> # read array data from file:
00524     >>> a = arr(file_='tmp.dat')
00525     >>> a
00526     array([[  1. ,   3. ],
00527            [  2. ,   6. ],
00528            [  3. ,  12. ],
00529            [  3.5,  20. ]])
00530     """
00531     if data is None and file_ is None and shape is None:
00532         return None
00533     
00534     if data is not None:
00535 
00536         if not operator.isSequenceType(data):
00537             raise TypeError, 'arr: data argument is not a sequence type'
00538         
00539         if isinstance(shape, (list,tuple)):
00540             # check that shape and data are compatible:
00541             if reduce(operator.mul, shape) != size(data):
00542                 raise ValueError, \
00543                       'arr: shape=%s is not compatible with %d '\
00544                       'elements in the provided data' % (shape, size(data))
00545         elif isinstance(shape, int):
00546             if shape != size(data):
00547                 raise ValueError, \
00548                       'arr: shape=%d is not compatible with %d '\
00549                       'elements in the provided data' % (shape, size(data))
00550         elif shape is None:
00551             if isinstance(data, (list,tuple)) and copy == False:
00552                 # cannot share data (data is list/tuple)
00553                 copy = True
00554             return array(data, element_type, copy=copy)
00555         else:
00556             raise TypeError, \
00557                   'shape is %s, must be list/tuple or int' % type(shape)
00558     elif file_ is not None:
00559         if not isinstance(file_, (basestring, file, StringIO)):
00560             raise TypeError, \
00561                   'file_ argument must be a string (filename) or '\
00562                   'open file object, not %s' % type(file_)
00563 
00564         if isinstance(file_, basestring):
00565             file_ = open(file_, 'r')
00566         # skip blank lines:
00567         while True:
00568             line1 = file_.readline().strip()
00569             if line1 != '':
00570                 break
00571         ncolumns = len(line1.split())
00572         file_.seek(0)
00573         # we assume that array data in file has element_type=float:
00574         if not element_type == float:
00575             raise ValueError, 'element_type must be float/"%s", not "%s"' % \
00576                   (float, element_type)
00577         
00578         d = array([float(word) for word in file_.read().split()])
00579         if isinstance(file_, basestring):
00580             f.close()
00581         # shape array d:
00582         if ncolumns > 1:
00583             suggested_shape = (int(len(d)/ncolumns), ncolumns)
00584             total_size = suggested_shape[0]*suggested_shape[1]
00585             if total_size != len(d):
00586                 raise ValueError, \
00587                 'found %d array entries in file "%s", but first line\n'\
00588                 'contains %d elements - no shape is compatible with\n'\
00589                 'these values' % (len(d), file, ncolumns)
00590             d.shape = suggested_shape
00591         if shape is not None:
00592             if shape != d.shape:
00593                 raise ValueError, \
00594                 'shape=%s is not compatible with shape %s found in "%s"' % \
00595                 (shape, d.shape, file)
00596         return d
00597     
00598     else:
00599         # no data, no file, just make zeros
00600 
00601         if isinstance(shape, NumPyArray):
00602             raise TypeError, \
00603            'arr: shape (1st arg) is NumPy array, must be tuple or int'
00604         if shape is None:
00605             raise ValueError, \
00606             'arr: either shape, data, or from_function must be specified'
00607 
00608         try:
00609             return zeros(shape, element_type)
00610         except MemoryError, e:
00611             # print more information (size of data):
00612             print e, 'of size %s' % shape
00613 
00614 # squeeze is from pylab
00615 def squeeze(a):
00616     "squeeze(a) returns a with any ones from the shape of a removed"
00617     a = asarray(a)
00618     b = asarray(a.shape)
00619     return reshape (a, tuple (compress (not_equal (b, 1), b)))
00620     
00621 def meshgrid(x=None, y=None, z=None, sparse=True):
00622     """
00623     Make 1D/2D/3D coordinate arrays for vectorized evaluations of
00624     1D/2D/3D scalar/vector fields over 1D/2D/3D grids, given
00625     one-dimensional coordinate arrays x, y, and/or, z.
00626 
00627     >>> x=seq(0,1,0.5)   # coordinate along x axis
00628     >>> y=seq(0,1,1)     # coordinate along y axis
00629     >>> meshgrid(x,y)    # extend x and y for a 2D xy grid
00630     (array([[ 0. ],
00631            [ 0.5],
00632            [ 1. ]]), array([       [ 0.,  1.]]))
00633     >>> z=5
00634     >>> meshgrid(x,y,z)  # 2D slice of a 3D grid, with z=const
00635     (array([[ 0. ],
00636            [ 0.5],
00637            [ 1. ]]), array([       [ 0.,  1.]]), 5)
00638     >>> xv, yv, zc = meshgrid(x,y,z)  # typical usage
00639 
00640     >>> meshgrid(2,y,x)  # 2D slice of a 3D grid, with x=const
00641     (2, array([[ 0.],
00642            [ 1.]]), array([       [ 0. ,  0.5,  1. ]]))
00643     >>> meshgrid(0,1,5)  # just a 3D point
00644     (0, 1, 5)
00645     >>> meshgrid(3)
00646     3
00647     >>> meshgrid(y)      # 1D grid; y is just returned
00648     array([ 0.,  1.])
00649     >>> meshgrid(x,y,sparse=False)  # store the full N-D matrix
00650     ([[ 0. , 0. , 0. ,]
00651      [ 0.5, 0.5, 0.5,]
00652      [ 1. , 1. , 1. ,]], [[ 0. , 0.5, 1. ,]
00653      [ 0. , 0.5, 1. ,]
00654      [ 0. , 0.5, 1. ,]])
00655 
00656     """
00657 
00658     # NOTE: numpy.mgrid defines a similar functionality, should use
00659     # that function if numpy is imported??
00660 
00661     if False:
00662         # convert list/tuple to NumPy arrays:
00663         if isinstance(x, (list,tuple)):  x = array(x)
00664         if isinstance(y, (list,tuple)):  y = array(y)
00665         if isinstance(z, (list,tuple)):  z = array(z)
00666 
00667         # Make sure output is dense when inputarray types are different
00668         if not sparse:
00669             if not basic_NumPy == NumPy_type(x):
00670                 print "Warning in meshgrid: converting x to %s" %basic_NumPy
00671                 x = asarray(x)
00672             if not basic_NumPy == NumPy_type(y):
00673                 print "Warning in meshgrid: converting y to %s" %basic_NumPy
00674                 y = asarray(y)
00675             if (z is not None) and not (basic_NumPy == NumPy_type(z)):
00676                 print "Warning in meshgrid: converting z to %s" %basic_NumPy
00677                 z = asarray(z)
00678     else:
00679         x = asarray(x)
00680         y = asarray(y)
00681         if z is not None:
00682             z = asarray(z)
00683 
00684     # Only singleton dimensions is allowed if rank > 1
00685     def squeeze(a):
00686         "squeeze(a) returns a with any ones from the shape of a removed"
00687         a = asarray(a)
00688         b = asarray(a.shape)
00689         return reshape (a, tuple (compress (not_equal (b, 1), b)))
00690         
00691     if rank(x) > 1: 
00692         x = squeeze(x)
00693         assert rank(x) == 1 
00694     if rank(y) >1:
00695         y = squeeze(y)
00696         assert rank(y) == 1
00697     if z is not None:
00698         if rank(z) >1:
00699             z = squeeze(z)
00700             assert rank(z) == 1
00701     
00702     
00703     # if x,y,z are identical, make copies:
00704     if y is x:  y = x.copy()
00705     if z is x:  z = x.copy()
00706     if z is y:  z = y.copy()
00707     
00708     import types
00709     def fixed(coor):
00710         return isinstance(coor, (float, complex, int, types.NoneType))
00711     
00712     def arr1D(coor):
00713         if isinstance(coor, NumPyArray):
00714             if len(coor.shape) == 1:
00715                 return True
00716         return False
00717     
00718     # if two of the arguments are fixed, we have a 1D grid, and
00719     # the third argument can be reused as is:
00720 
00721     if arr1D(x) and fixed(y) and fixed(z):
00722         return x
00723     if fixed(x) and arr1D(y) and fixed(z):
00724         return y
00725     if fixed(x) and fixed(y) and arr1D(z):
00726         return z
00727 
00728     mult_fact = 1
00729     # if the sparse argument is False, the full N-D matrix (not only the 1-D
00730     # vector) should be returned. The mult_fact variable should then be updated
00731     # as necessary.
00732 
00733     # if only one argument is fixed, we have a 2D grid:
00734     if arr1D(x) and arr1D(y) and fixed(z):
00735         if not sparse:
00736             mult_fact = ones((len(x),len(y)))
00737         if z is None:
00738             return x[:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, y[NewAxis,:]*mult_fact
00739         else:
00740             return x[:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, y[NewAxis,:]*mult_fact, z
00741         
00742     if arr1D(x) and fixed(y) and arr1D(z):
00743         if not sparse:
00744             mult_fact = ones((len(x),len(z)))
00745         if y is None:
00746             return x[:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, z[NewAxis,:]*mult_fact
00747         else:
00748             return x[:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, y, z[NewAxis,:]*mult_fact
00749         
00750     if fixed(x) and arr1D(y) and arr1D(z):
00751         if not sparse:
00752             mult_fact = ones((len(y),len(z)))
00753         if x is None:
00754             return y[:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, z[NewAxis,:]*mult_fact
00755         else:
00756             return x, y[:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, z[NewAxis,:]*mult_fact
00757 
00758     # or maybe we have a full 3D grid:
00759     if arr1D(x) and arr1D(y) and arr1D(z):
00760         if not sparse:
00761             mult_fact = ones((len(x),len(y),len(z)))
00762         return x[:,NewAxis,NewAxis]*mult_fact, \
00763                y[NewAxis,:,NewAxis]*mult_fact, \
00764                z[NewAxis,NewAxis,:]*mult_fact
00765 
00766     # at this stage we assume that we just have scalars:
00767     l = []
00768     if x is not None:
00769         l.append(x)
00770     if y is not None:
00771         l.append(y)
00772     if z is not None:
00773         l.append(z)
00774     if len(l) == 1:
00775         return l[0]
00776     else:
00777         return tuple(l)
00778      
00779         
00780 def float_eq(a, b, rtol=1.0e-14, atol=1.0e-14):
00781     """
00782     Approximate test a==b for float variables.
00783     Returns true if abs(a-b) < atol + rtol*abs(b).
00784     atol comes into play when abs(b) is very small.
00785     When a and b are NumPy arrays, NumPy's allclose function is called
00786     (but float_eq's default tolerances are much stricter than those of
00787     allclose).
00788     """
00789     if isinstance(a, float):
00790         return math.fabs(a-b) < atol + rtol*math.fabs(b)
00791     elif isinstance(a, NumPyArray):
00792         return allclose(a, b, rtol, atol)
00793     elif isinstance(a, complex):
00794         return float_eq(a.real, b.real, rtol, atol) and \
00795                float_eq(a.imag, b.imag, rtol, atol)
00796     else:
00797         raise TypeError, 'Illegal types: a is %s and b is %s' % \
00798               (type(a), type(b))
00799     
00800 
00801 def norm_l2(u):
00802     """
00803     l2 norm of a multi-dimensional array u viewed as a vector
00804     (norm=sqrt(dot(u.flat,u.flat))).
00805     """
00806     return math.sqrt(innerproduct(u.flat, u.flat))
00807 
00808 def norm_L2(u):
00809     """
00810     L2 norm of a multi-dimensional array u viewed as a vector
00811     (norm=sqrt(dot(u.flat,u.flat)/n)).
00812 
00813     If u holds function values and the norm of u is supposed to
00814     approximate an integral (L2 norm) of the function, this (and
00815     not norm_l2) is the right norm function to use.
00816     """
00817     return norm_l2(u)/sqrt(float(size(u)))
00818 
00819 def norm_l1(u):
00820     """
00821     l1 norm of a multi-dimensional array u viewed as a vector
00822     (norm=sum(abs(u.flat))).
00823     """
00824     return sum(abs(u.flat))
00825 
00826 def norm_L1(u):
00827     """
00828     L1 norm of a multi-dimensional array u viewed as a vector
00829     (norm=sum(abs(u.flat))).
00830 
00831     If u holds function values and the norm of u is supposed to
00832     approximate an integral (L1 norm) of the function, this (and
00833     not norm_l1) is the right norm function to use.
00834     """
00835     return norm_l1(u)/float(size(u))
00836 
00837 def norm_inf(u):
00838     """Infinity/max norm of a multi-dimensional array u viewed as a vector."""
00839     return arrmax(abs(u.flat))
00840 
00841 
00842 
00843 def solve_tridiag_linear_system(A, b):
00844     """
00845     Solve a tridiagonal linear system of the form::
00846     
00847      A[0,1]*x[0] + A[0,2]*x[1]                                        = 0
00848      A[1,0]*x[0] + A[1,1]*x[1] + A[1,2]*x[2]                          = 0
00849      ...
00850      ...
00851               A[k,0]*x[k-1] + A[k,1]*x[k] + A[k,2]*x[k+1]             = 0
00852      ...
00853                   A[n-2,0]*x[n-3] + A[n-2,1]*x[n-2] + A[n-2,2]*x[n-1] = 0
00854      ...
00855                                     A[n-1,0]*x[n-2] + A[n-1,1]*x[n-1] = 0
00856 
00857     That is, the diagonal is stored in A[:,1], the subdiagonal
00858     is stored in A[1:,0], and the superdiagonal is stored in A[:n-2,2].
00859 
00860     The storage is not memory friendly in Python/C (diagonals in
00861     the columns of A, but when A is sent to F77 for high-performance
00862     computing, a copy is taken and the F77 routine works with the
00863     same algorithm and hence optimal Fortran storage.
00864     """
00865     n = len(b)
00866     x = zeros(n, float)  # solution
00867     d = zeros(n, float);  c = zeros(n, float);  m = zeros(n, float)
00868 
00869     d[0] = A[0,1]
00870     c[0] = b[0]
00871 
00872     for k in isequence(1, n-1, 1):
00873         m[k] = A[k,0]/d[k-1]
00874         d[k] = A[k,1] - m[k]*A[k-1,2]
00875         c[k] = b[k] - m[k]*c[k-1]
00876     x[n-1] = c[n-1]/d[n-1]
00877 
00878     # back substitution:
00879     for k in isequence(n-2, 0, -1):
00880         x[k] = (c[k] - A[k,2]*x[k+1])/d[k]
00881     return x
00882 
00883 
00884 
00885 
00886 try:
00887     import Pmw
00888     class NumPy2BltVector(Pmw.Blt.Vector):
00889         """
00890         Copy a NumPy array to a BLT vector:
00891         # a: some NumPy array
00892         b = NumPy2BltVector(a)  # b is BLT vector
00893         g = Pmw.Blt.Graph(someframe)
00894         # send b to g for plotting
00895         """
00896         def __init__(self, array):
00897             Pmw.Blt.Vector.__init__(self, len(array))
00898             self.set(tuple(array))  # copy elements
00899 except:
00900     class NumPy2BltVector:
00901         def __init__(self, array):
00902             raise ImportError, "Python is not compiled with BLT"
00903 
00904 try:
00905     from graphics.StringFunction import StringFunction
00906 except:
00907     pass  # wrap2callable may not work
00908 
00909 
00910 class WrapNo2Callable:
00911     """Turn a number (constant) into a callable function."""
00912     def __init__(self, constant):
00913         self.constantconstant = constant
00914         self._array_shape_array_shape = None
00915 
00916     def __call__(self, *args):
00917         """
00918         >>> w = WrapNo2Callable(4.4)
00919         >>> w(99)
00920         4.4000000000000004
00921         >>> # try vectorized computations:
00922         >>> x = seq(1, 4, 1)
00923         >>> y = seq(1, 2)
00924         >>> xv = x[:,NewAxis]; yv = y[NewAxis,:]
00925         >>> xv + yv
00926         array([[ 2.,  3.],
00927                [ 3.,  4.],
00928                [ 4.,  5.],
00929                [ 5.,  6.]])
00930         >>> w(xv, yv)
00931         array([[ 4.4,  4.4],
00932                [ 4.4,  4.4],
00933                [ 4.4,  4.4],
00934                [ 4.4,  4.4]])
00935 
00936         If you want to call such a function object with space-time
00937         arguments and vectorized expressions, make sure the time
00938         argument is not the first argument. That is,
00939         w(xv, yv, t) is fine, but w(t, xv, yv) will return 4.4,
00940         not the desired array!
00941         """
00942         if isinstance(args[0], NumPyArray):
00943             if self._array_shape_array_shape is None:
00944                 self._set_array_shape_set_array_shape()
00945             else:
00946                 r = self.constantconstant*ones(self._array_shape_array_shape, float)
00947                 # could store r (allocated once) and just return reference
00948                 return r
00949         else:
00950             # scalar version:
00951             return self.constantconstant
00952 
00953     def _set_array_shape(self, arg):
00954         # vectorized version:
00955         r = arg.copy()
00956         # to get right dimension of the return array,
00957         # compute with args in a simple formula (sum of args)
00958         for a in args[1:]:
00959             r = r + a  # in-place r+= won't work
00960             # (handles x,y,t - the last t just adds a constant)
00961             # an argument sequence t, x, y  will fail (1st arg
00962             # is not a NumPy array)
00963         self._array_shape_array_shape = r.shape
00964 
00965     # The problem with this class is that, in the vectorized version,
00966     # the array shape is determined in the first call, i.e., later
00967     # calls may return an array with the wrong shape if the shape of
00968     # the input arguments change! Sometimes, when called along boundaries
00969     # of grids, the shape may change so the next implementation is
00970     # slower and safer.
00971     
00972 class WrapNo2Callable:
00973     """Turn a number (constant) into a callable function."""
00974     def __init__(self, constant):
00975         self.constantconstant = constant
00976 
00977     def __call__(self, *args):
00978         """
00979         >>> w = WrapNo2Callable(4.4)
00980         >>> w(99)
00981         4.4000000000000004
00982         >>> # try vectorized computations:
00983         >>> x = seq(1, 4, 1)
00984         >>> y = seq(1, 2)
00985         >>> xv = x[:,NewAxis]; yv = y[NewAxis,:]
00986         >>> xv + yv
00987         array([[ 2.,  3.],
00988                [ 3.,  4.],
00989                [ 4.,  5.],
00990                [ 5.,  6.]])
00991         >>> w(xv, yv)
00992         array([[ 4.4,  4.4],
00993                [ 4.4,  4.4],
00994                [ 4.4,  4.4],
00995                [ 4.4,  4.4]])
00996 
00997         If you want to call such a function object with space-time
00998         arguments and vectorized expressions, make sure the time
00999         argument is not the first argument. That is,
01000         w(xv, yv, t) is fine, but w(t, xv, yv) will return 4.4,
01001         not the desired array!
01002                
01003         """
01004         if isinstance(args[0], NumPyArray):
01005             # vectorized version:
01006             r = args[0].copy()
01007             # to get right dimension of the return array,
01008             # compute with args in a simple formula (sum of args)
01009             for a in args[1:]:
01010                 r = r + a  # in-place r+= won't work
01011                 # (handles x,y,t - the last t just adds a constant)
01012             r[:] = self.constantconstant
01013             return r
01014         else:
01015             # scalar version:
01016             return self.constantconstant
01017 
01018 
01019 class WrapDiscreteData2Callable:
01020     """
01021     Turn discrete data on a uniform grid into a callable function,
01022     i.e., equip the data with an interpolation function.
01023 
01024     >>> from graphics.numpytools import *
01025     >>> x = seq(0,1,0.1)
01026     >>> y = 1+2*x
01027     >>> f = wrap2callable((x,y))
01028     >>> f(0.5)   # evaluate f(x)
01029     1.5
01030     >>> f(0.5, 0.1)  # discrete data with extra time prm: f(x,t)
01031     1.5
01032     """
01033     def __init__(self, data):
01034         self.datadata = data  # (x,y,f) data for an f(x,y) function
01035         from Scientific.Functions.Interpolation \
01036              import InterpolatingFunction # from ScientificPython
01037         self.interpolating_functioninterpolating_function = \
01038              InterpolatingFunction(self.datadata[:-1], self.datadata[-1])
01039         self.ndimsndims = len(self.datadata[:-1])  # no of spatial dim.
01040         
01041     def __call__(self, *args):
01042         # allow more arguments (typically time) after spatial pos.:
01043         args = args[:self.ndimsndims]
01044         # args can be tuple of scalars (point) or tuple of vectors
01045         if isinstance(args[0], (float, int)):
01046             return self.interpolating_functioninterpolating_function(*args)
01047         else:
01048             # args is tuple of vectors; Interpolation must work
01049             # with one point at a time:
01050             r = [self.interpolating_functioninterpolating_function(*a) for a in zip(*args)]
01051             return array(r)  # wrap in NumPy array
01052 
01053         
01054 def wrap2callable(f, **kwargs):
01055     """
01056     Allow constants, string formulas, discrete data points,
01057     user-defined functions and (callable) classes to be wrapped
01058     in a new callable function. That is, all the mentioned data
01059     structures can be used as a function, usually of space and/or
01060     time.
01061     (kwargs is used for string formulas)
01062 
01063     >>> from graphics.numpytools import *
01064     >>> f1 = wrap2callable(2.0)
01065     >>> f1(0.5)
01066     2.0
01067     >>> f2 = wrap2callable('1+2*x')
01068     >>> f2(0.5)
01069     2.0
01070     >>> f3 = wrap2callable('1+2*t', independent_variables='t')
01071     >>> f3(0.5)
01072     2.0
01073     >>> f4 = wrap2callable('a+b*t')
01074     >>> f4(0.5)
01075     Traceback (most recent call last):
01076     ...
01077     NameError: name 'a' is not defined
01078     >>> f4 = wrap2callable('a+b*t', independent_variables='t', \
01079                            a=1, b=2)
01080     >>> f4(0.5)
01081     2.0
01082 
01083     >>> x = seq(0,1,0.5); y=1+2*x
01084     >>> f5 = wrap2callable((x,y))
01085     >>> f5(0.5)
01086     2.0
01087     >>> def myfunc(x):  return 1+2*x
01088     >>> f6 = wrap2callable(myfunc)
01089     >>> f6(0.5)
01090     2.0
01091     >>> f7 = wrap2callable(lambda x: 1+2*x)
01092     >>> f7(0.5)
01093     2.0
01094     >>> class MyClass:
01095             'Representation of a function f(x; a, b) =a + b*x'
01096             def __init__(self, a=1, b=1):
01097                 self.a = a;  self.b = b
01098             def __call__(self, x):
01099                 return self.a + self.b*x
01100     >>> myclass = MyClass(a=1, b=2)
01101     >>> f8 = wrap2callable(myclass)
01102     >>> f8(0.5)
01103     2.0
01104     >>> # 3D functions:
01105     >>> f9 = wrap2callable('1+2*x+3*y+4*z', \
01106                            independent_variables=('x','y','z'))
01107     >>> f9(0.5,1/3.,0.25)
01108     4.0
01109     >>> # discrete 3D data:
01110     >>> y = seq(0,1,0.5); z = seq(-1,0.5,0.1)
01111     >>> xc = x[:,NewAxis,NewAxis]; yc = y[NewAxis,:,NewAxis]
01112     >>> zc = z[NewAxis,NewAxis,:]
01113     >>> def myfunc3(x,y,z):  return 1+2*x+3*y+4*z
01114 
01115     >>> values = myfunc3(xc,yc,zc)
01116     >>> f10 = wrap2callable((x,y,z,values))
01117     >>> f10(0.5,1/3.,0.25)
01118     4.0
01119 
01120     One can also check what the object is wrapped as and do more
01121     specific operations, e.g.,
01122     
01123     >>> f9.__class__.__name__
01124     'StringFunction'
01125     >>> str(f9)     # look at function formula
01126     '1+2*x+3*y+4*z'
01127     >>> f8.__class__.__name__
01128     'MyClass'
01129     >>> f8.a, f8.b  # access MyClass-specific data
01130     (1, 2)
01131 
01132     Troubleshooting regarding string functions:
01133     If you use a string formula with a NumPy array, you typically get
01134     error messages like::
01135         
01136        TypeError: only rank-0 arrays can be converted to Python scalars.
01137     
01138     You must then make the right::
01139 
01140        from Numeric/numarray/graphics.numpytools import *
01141        
01142     in the calling code and supply the keyword argument::
01143         
01144        globals=globals()
01145        
01146     to wrap2callable. See also the documentation of class StringFunction
01147     for more information.
01148     """
01149     if isinstance(f, str):
01150         return StringFunction(f, **kwargs)
01151         # this is a considerable optimization (up to a factor of 3),
01152         # but then the additional info in the StringFunction instance
01153         # is lost in the calling code:
01154         # return StringFunction(f, **kwargs).__call__
01155     elif isinstance(f, (float, int)):
01156         return WrapNo2Callable(f)
01157     elif isinstance(f, (list,tuple)):
01158         return WrapDiscreteData2Callable(f)
01159     elif operator.isCallable(f):
01160         return f
01161     else:
01162         raise TypeError, 'f of type %s is not callable' % type(f)
01163 
01164 
01165 # problem: setitem in ArrayGen does not support multiple indices
01166 # relying on inherited __setitem__ works fine
01167 
01168 def NumPy_array_iterator(a, **kwargs):
01169     """
01170     Iterate over all elements in a NumPy array a.
01171     Return values: generator function and the code of this function.
01172 
01173     The keyword arguments specify offsets in the start and stop value
01174     of the index in each dimension. Legal values are
01175     offset0_start, offset0_stop, offset1_start, offset1_stop, etc.
01176     Also offset_start and offset_stop are legal keyword arguments,
01177     these imply the same offset value for all dimensions.
01178     
01179     Examples::
01180     
01181     >>> q = seq(1, 2*3*4, 1);  q.shape = (2,3,4)
01182     >>> it, code = NumPy_array_iterator(q)
01183     >>> print code  # generator function with 3 nested loops:
01184     def nested_loops(a):
01185         for i0 in xrange(0, a.shape[0]-0):
01186             for i1 in xrange(0, a.shape[1]-0):
01187                 for i2 in xrange(0, a.shape[2]-0):
01188                     yield a[i0, i1, i2], (i0, i1, i2)
01189     >>> type(it)
01190     <type 'function'>
01191     >>> for value, index in it(q):
01192     ...     print 'a%s = %g' % (index, value)
01193     ...
01194     a(0, 0, 0) = 1
01195     a(0, 0, 1) = 2
01196     a(0, 0, 2) = 3
01197     a(0, 0, 3) = 4
01198     a(0, 1, 0) = 5
01199     a(0, 1, 1) = 6
01200     a(0, 1, 2) = 7
01201     a(0, 1, 3) = 8
01202     a(0, 2, 0) = 9
01203     a(0, 2, 1) = 10
01204     a(0, 2, 2) = 11
01205     a(0, 2, 3) = 12
01206     a(1, 0, 0) = 13
01207     a(1, 0, 1) = 14
01208     a(1, 0, 2) = 15
01209     a(1, 0, 3) = 16
01210     a(1, 1, 0) = 17
01211     a(1, 1, 1) = 18
01212     a(1, 1, 2) = 19
01213     a(1, 1, 3) = 20
01214     a(1, 2, 0) = 21
01215     a(1, 2, 1) = 22
01216     a(1, 2, 2) = 23
01217     a(1, 2, 3) = 24
01218 
01219     Now let us try some offsets::
01220 
01221     >>> it, code = NumPy_array_iterator(q, offset1_stop=1, offset_start=1)
01222     >>> print code
01223     def nested_loops(a):
01224         for i0 in xrange(1, a.shape[0]-0):
01225             for i1 in xrange(1, a.shape[1]-1):
01226                 for i2 in xrange(1, a.shape[2]-0):
01227                     yield a[i0, i1, i2], (i0, i1, i2)
01228     >>> # note: the offsets appear in the xrange arguments
01229     >>> for value, index in it(q):
01230     ...     print 'a%s = %g' % (index, value)
01231     ...
01232     a(1, 1, 1) = 18
01233     a(1, 1, 2) = 19
01234     a(1, 1, 3) = 20
01235     """
01236     # build the code of the generator function in a text string
01237     # (since the number of nested loops needed to iterate over all
01238     # elements are parameterized through len(a.shape))
01239     dims = range(len(a.shape))
01240     offset_code1 = ['offset%d_start=0' % d for d in dims]
01241     offset_code2 = ['offset%d_stop=0'  % d for d in dims]
01242     for d in range(len(a.shape)):
01243         key1 = 'offset%d_start' % d
01244         key2 = 'offset%d_stop' % d
01245         if key1 in kwargs.keys():
01246             offset_code1.append(key1 + '=' + str(kwargs[key1]))
01247         if key2 in kwargs.keys():
01248             offset_code2.append(key2 + '=' + str(kwargs[key2]))
01249         
01250     for key in kwargs:
01251         if key == 'offset_start':
01252             offset_code1.extend(['offset%d_start=%d' % (d, kwargs[key]) \
01253                             for d in range(len(a.shape))])
01254         if key == 'offset_stop':
01255             offset_code2.extend(['offset%d_stop=%d' % (d, kwargs[key]) \
01256                             for d in range(len(a.shape))])
01257 
01258     for line in offset_code1:
01259         exec line
01260     for line in offset_code2:
01261         exec line
01262     code = 'def nested_loops(a):\n'
01263     indentation = ' '*4
01264     indent = '' + indentation
01265     for dim in range(len(a.shape)):
01266         code += indent + \
01267         'for i%d in xrange(%d, a.shape[%d]-%d):\n' \
01268                 % (dim, eval('offset%d_start' % dim),
01269                    dim, eval('offset%d_stop' % dim))
01270         indent += indentation
01271     index = ', '.join(['i%d' % d for d in range(len(a.shape))])
01272     code += indent + 'yield ' + 'a[%s]' % index + ', (' + index + ')'
01273     exec code
01274     return nested_loops, code
01275 
01276 
01277 def NumPy_type(a):
01278     """
01279     @param a: NumPy array
01280     @return:  "Numeric", "numarray", or "numpy", depending on which
01281     module that was used to generate the a array
01282     """
01283     import Numeric
01284     if isinstance(a, Numeric.ArrayType):
01285         return 'Numeric'
01286     import numarray
01287     if isinstance(a, numarray.NumArray):
01288         return 'numarray'
01289     import numpy
01290     if isinstance(a, numpy.ndarray):
01291         return 'numpy'
01292     
01293 
01294 def fortran_storage(a):
01295     """
01296     Transparent transform of a NumPy array to Fortran (column major)
01297     storage.
01298 
01299     @param a:  NumPy array (generated in Python or C with C storage)
01300     @return: a new NumPy array with column major storage.
01301 
01302     Method: If a is of numpy type, numpy.asarray(a, fortran=True)
01303     is used to produce the new array.
01304     If a is of Numeric or numarray type, we want to preserve the array type
01305     and use a simple (and slower) transpose(transpose(a).copy()) instead.
01306     """
01307     if NumPy_type(a) == 'Numeric' or NumPy_type(a) == 'numarray':
01308         return transpose(transpose(a).copy())
01309     else:
01310         import numpy
01311         return numpy.asarray(a, fortran=True)
01312     
01313             
01314 def _doctest():
01315     import doctest, numpytools
01316     return doctest.testmod(numpytools)
01317 
01318 # Short forms:
01319 fft = FFT
01320 #mlab = MLab
01321 try:
01322     ma = MA
01323 except NameError:
01324     # for Numeric we do not import MA since it affects output format
01325     pass
01326 ra = RandomArray
01327 la = LinearAlgebra 
01328     
01329 def verify(N, namecheck = ['fft','mlab','ma','ra','la']):
01330     """
01331     Verify that some packages imported by numpytools 
01332     works for Numeric, numarray, or numpy.
01333     """
01334     print "\nUsing %s in %s" % (N.basic_NumPy, N.__name__)
01335     for name in namecheck:
01336         print "%s.%s : %s " % (
01337             N.__name__,
01338             name,
01339             eval("N.%s.__name__" %name))
01340     print ""
01341 
01342 def _test1():
01343     """Call verify function for N as Numeric, numarray, and numpy."""
01344     sys.argv.append('--Numeric')
01345     import numpytools as N
01346     verify(N)
01347     sys.argv[-1] = '--numarray'
01348     reload(N)
01349     verify(N)
01350     sys.argv[-1] = '--numpy'
01351     reload(N)
01352     verify(N)

01355 if __name__ == '__main__':
01356 
01357     #_test1()
01358 
01359     #test_ArrayGen()
01360     #_doctest()  # does not work properly with wrap2callable
01361     
01362     # Test meshgrid function
01363     import unittest
01364     import numpytools as N
01365 
01366     class numpytoolsTest(unittest.TestCase):
01367         def setUp(self):
01368             pass
01369 
01370         def testMeshgrid(self):
01371             #print 'testing Meshgrid'
01372             x = N.arange(10)
01373             y = N.arange(4)
01374             z = N.arange(3)
01375             X, Y, Z = N.meshgrid(x, y, z, sparse=False)
01376             assert N.rank(X) == 3
01377 
01378         def testMeshgrid_DenseFromMixedArrayTypes(self):
01379             # Other combination of arrays
01380             #print 'testing Meshgrid with mixed array implementations'
01381             y = N.arange(4)
01382             z = N.arange(3)
01383             
01384             import Numeric
01385             x = Numeric.arange(10)
01386             X, Y, Z = N.meshgrid(x, y, z, sparse=False)
01387             if not  N.rank(X) == 3:
01388                 raise AssertionError, \
01389                       "Meshgrid failed with arraytype mix of  Numeric and %s"\
01390                       %N.basic_NumPy
01391             import numarray
01392             x = numarray.arange(10)
01393             X, Y, Z = N.meshgrid(x, y, z, sparse=False)
01394 
01395             if not  N.rank(X) == 3:
01396                 raise AssertionError, \
01397                       "Meshgrid failed with arraytype mix of numarray and %s"\
01398                       %N.basic_NumPy
01399 
01400             import numpy
01401             x = numpy.arange(10)
01402             X, Y, Z = N.meshgrid(x, y, z, sparse=False)
01403             #assert N.rank(X) == 3
01404             if not  N.rank(X) == 3:
01405                 raise AssertionError, \
01406                       "Meshgrid failed with arraytype mix of numpy and %s"\
01407                       %N.basic_NumPy
01408             
01409         def testMeshGrid_DenseFromNodenseMeshgridOutput(self):
01410             # sparse fails for dense output when input has singleton dimensions
01411             x = seq(-2,2,0.1)
01412             y = seq(-4,4,1)
01413             xx, yy = meshgrid(x,y) # xx and yy now has singleton dimension
01414             self.assertEqual(rank(xx), 2) 
01415             self.assertEqual(rank(yy), 2)
01416             self.assertEqual(multiply.reduce(xx.shape), size(xx)) 
01417             self.assertEqual(multiply.reduce(yy.shape), size(yy))
01418             # This one should fail when xx and yy is not flat as well
01419             xx, yy = meshgrid(xx.flat, yy.flat, sparse=False) # no singleton
01420             self.assertEqual(shape(xx), (size(x), size(y)))
01421             self.assertEqual(shape(yy), (size(x), size(y)))
01422             
01423             xx, yy = meshgrid(x,y) # Add singleton dimensions
01424             xx, yy = meshgrid(xx, yy, sparse=False) 
01425             self.assertEqual(shape(xx), (size(x), size(y)))
01426             self.assertEqual(shape(yy), (size(x), size(y)))
01427 
01428             #from IPython.Shell import IPythonShellEmbed as magic
01429             #magic()('from unittest')
01430             
01431     sys.argv.append('--Numeric')
01432     for arg in ['--Numeric', '--numarray', ' --numpy']:
01433         sys.argv[-1] = arg
01434         print '\nNow testing with system arg %10s\n%s' %(arg, '='*38)
01435         reload(N);  N.verify(N)
01436         suite = unittest.makeSuite(numpytoolsTest)
01437         unittest.TextTestRunner(verbosity=2).run(suite)
